DOC.HEAD: U.S. Lieutenant Shoots Panama Corporal in Second Incident
Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Panamanian denial, further details, quotes, minor editing. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. lieutenant shot and wounded a Panamanian corporal near an American installation Monday, U.S. officials reported. It was the second shooting incident in three days between U.S. and Panamanian forces. On Saturday, Panamanian soldiers shot and killed an American officer near Panamanian military headquarters. President Bush on Monday called that shooting ``an enormous outrage'' and said he would not rule out military action. A U.S. Southern Command statement said that on Monday an American was leaving a U.S. Army laundry in the Curundu area of western Panama City when a uniformed Panamanian signaled him to stop and approached him. The area is near Southern Command headquarters and less than a mile from Panamanian Defense Forces headquarters. The statement said the U.S. officer fired when the Panamanian appeared to reach for a weapon. ``The American responded defensively by pulling a weapon and fired two shots,'' it said. ``The Panamanian went down, then got up and left the scene. The extent of his injuries is unknown at this time.'' U.S. officials said the officer was being ``debriefed.'' A Panamanian Defense Forces communique later called it ``reckless aggression'' by the U.S. Army. It said the American ``fired two shots from a firearm, one of them hitting the left forearm'' of policeman Cesar Tejada. It said the American was traveling in a vehicle that ``never stopped and on the contrary, accelerated.'' The communique said Tejada was hospitalized, but did not give his condition. Capt. Moises Cortizo, Panama's chief of police, said police were investigating. According to a Command official, the civilian laundry has a contract to clean uniforms for U.S. forces. In Washington, a Defense Department official, speaking on condition of anonymity, gave this account: A Panamanian traffic officer signaled the American to stop and approached his car. The Panamanian pulled his weapon ``and the lieutenant did the same.'' The American fired two shots and it was believed the Panamanian was wounded in a leg and an arm. Tensions still were high at the time because of Saturday's death. Panamanian officials said the U.S. Army commander in Panama threatened an invasion. ``This is the most serious incident we have had,'' a Command spokesman said. ``This involved a loss of life. No course of action is being ruled out as a response.'' ``We are trying to be rational in our response. We are going to take a calculated plan of action. The U.S. government does not respond without thinking results through.'' He spoke on the condition of anonymity. Photographs of the 1981 Chevrolet with Michigan plates in which the Americans were riding showed bullet holes, including two on the driver's side and one through the trunk. U.S. officers said the shots came from Soviet-made AK rifles. The United States has taken no visible action since Saturday other than to put its forces on maximum alert and display them visibly in its military installations. The Pentagon said the officer was fatally shot and a Navy officer and his wife were arrested and beaten Saturday night not far from the military headquarters of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian leader. Panamanian Lt. Col. Arnulfo Castrejon Garcia on Monday called ``completely false'' allegations that the couple were mistreated, though he confirmed they were arrested. U.S. troops in battle gear patrolled perimeter fences at their bases Monday and Panamanian troops blocked the street in front of the military headquarters, but life was normal in the rest of the city. U.S. and Panamanian forces were holding a ``dialogue'' by messenger, Castrejon told reporters. He said the U.S. Army South commander, Gen. Marc Cisneros, had threatened an invasion. Asked why the United States had not already invaded, Castrejon said, ``It could be they realize they went through the checkpoint.'' A spokesman for the U.S. Southern Command, which controls all U.S. forces in Panama, including U.S. Army South, said he could not comment on Castrejon's statements. The Associated Press learned Panama's Defense Forces sent a letter to U.S. military officials apparently trying to gain time following the U.S. demand for an explanation. The Panamanian military said the letter ``demanded that U.S. forces exercise maximum prudence to avoid unfortunate incidents.'' It said U.S. forces ``disregarded our observations resulting in unfortunate incidents as the one which occurred on the evening of Dec. 16.'' A U.S. military source said there had been no ``negotiations'' with the Panamanians concerning the incident. The United States said Panamanian troops were solely responsible for the violence Saturday, that the U.S. officer and three companions took a wrong turn and were lost. The Defense Forces accused U.S. officers of provocation and said they ran through a Defense Forces checkpoint. In Washington, the White House said the violence was a ``consequence'' of Panama's being run by Noriega. Since February 1988, when Noriega was indicted in Florida on narcotics charges, the United States has tried to drive him from power with economic, diplomatic and political pressure. Noriega denies the charges. He claims Washington wants to renege on treaties under which the United States is to transfer control of the canal to Panama at the end of the century and close U.S. military installations. Thousands of U.S. soldiers lived in Panama City until earlier this year, when they and their dependents were ordered to move onto the bases. Many dependents returned to the United States. The Command confirmed that the transfer of civilian dependents from military posts ``was being stepped up.'' The number of families still on post is 500, down from 3,200 last May.
